title: Sals recover fumbles, drop Middletown
text:
Sals recover fumbles, drop Middletown Brad Myers , The News Journal 5:06 a.m. EDT October 10, 2015 The Sals celebrate their 20-6 win against Middletown as time expires at Baynard Stadium Friday. WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNA Salesianum's Joshua Patrick (right) helps on a tackle of Middletown's Kedrick Whitehead in the second quarter of the Sals' 20-6 win at Baynard Stadium Friday. WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNA Salesianum's Colby Reeder (left) tries to bring down Middletown's Jalen Whitehead in the second quarter of the Sals' 20-6 win at Baynard Stadium Friday. WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNA Salesianum's Marek Easton (center) is met by teammates William Stradley (left) and Mitchell Sgro after a fumble recovery for a Middletown turnover in the second quarter of the Sals' 20-6 win at Baynard Stadium Friday. WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNA Salesianum punt returner Jeremy Ryan collects a kick from Middletown punter Tyler Bierlein (67) as Cavalier Alex Weber covers in the second quarter of the Sals' 20-6 win at Baynard Stadium Friday. WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNA Salesianum's Zachary Jerome (left) gains yards as Middletown's Khari Griffin spins to face him in the second quarter of the Sals' 20-6 win at Baynard Stadium Friday. WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNA Fullscreen Buy Photo Salesianum quarterback Garrett Cannon looks for a receiver in the second quarter of the Sals' 20-6 win at Baynard Stadium Friday. WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNAL Middletown's Kedrick Whitehead (3) leaves the Sals defense, including (from left) Mitchell Sgro, Zach Jarome, Kyle Cathers and Griffin Salvo behind on a 74-yard touchdown run in the third quarter of the Sals' 20-6 win at Baynard Stadium Friday. WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNA Salesianum's Jeremy Ryan (left) tries to avoid Middletown's Steven Sapp (center) Alexander Weber (19) and Alexis Green in the third quarter of the Sals' 20-6 win at Baynard Stadium Friday. WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNA Middletown's Lyle Bryant tries to vault his teammates but is tripped up at the line in the third quarter of the Sals' 20-6 win at Baynard Stadium Friday. WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNA Salesianum's Colby Reeder tries to get past Middletown's Kedrick Whitehead in the fourth quarter of the Sals' 20-6 win at Baynard Stadium Friday. WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNA Middletown's Vincent Delpercio lets a third quarter pass fly in the Sals' 20-6 win at Baynard Stadium Friday. WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNA Salesianum linebacker William Stradley drives into Middletown quarterback Vincent Delpercio in the third quarter of the Sals' 20-6 win at Baynard Stadium Friday. WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNA Salesianum's Griffin Salvo leaves Middletown's Peter Cox behind on a 25-yard touchdown run in the third quarter of the Sals' 20-6 win at Baynard Stadium Friday. WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNA The Middletown band plays on as the Cavaliers try to get their offense going in the second half of the Sals' 20-6 win at Baynard Stadium Friday. WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNA Salesianum's Jamal Whittlesey (left) is slowed by Middletown's Chris Weatherford as Vincent Delpercio lets a pass go in the fourth quarter of the Sals' 20-6 win at Baynard Stadium Friday. WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNA Middletown's Isiah Mitchell accepts a pass in the fourth quarter of the Sals' 20-6 win at Baynard Stadium Friday. WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNA Salesianum's Colby Reeder (left) cuts at the line and tries to avoid Alex Finch in the fourth quarter of the Sals' 20-6 win at Baynard Stadium Friday. WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNA Saleianum punter William Frangia gets a kick away after a bouncing snap at his goal line as Colby Reeder smothers Middletown's Kedrick Whitehead in the fourth quarter of the Sals' 20-6 win at Baynard Stadium Friday. WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNA Middletown's Kenneth Edelin is hit by Salesianum's Griffin Salvo as he catches a fourth quarter pass in the Sals' 20-6 win at Baynard Stadium Friday. WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNA The Sals celebrate with the classmates after beating Middletown 20-6 at Baynard Stadium Friday. WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNA Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Salesianum's Colby Reeder tries to get past Middletown's Kedrick Whitehead in the fourth quarter of the Sals' 20-6 win at Baynard Stadium Friday. (Photo: WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNA) 
WILMINGTON When a pregame thunderstorm drenched Baynard Stadium and delayed the kickoff for 24 minutes, Middletown and Salesianum knew the ball would be wet and slippery. 
The Cavaliers fumbled it. The Sals held on to it. And that made all the difference. 
Kyle Cathers and Marek Easton each recovered two fumbles, and Colby Reeder rushed 30 times for 181 yards and a touchdown as No. 3 Salesianum sloshed to a 20-6 victory over No. 2 Middletown on Friday night. 
The Sals (4-1) didn’t do anything spectacular on the attack. But since its three scoring drives only covered a combined 58 yards following Cavaliers turnovers, Salesianum didn’t really need a big offensive game. 
“I was very happy with our kids. We forced a lot of turnovers,” Sallies coach Bill DiNardo said. “We were very opportunistic. 
“I thought our defense played great. Our offense, we did what we had to do.” 
Middletown fumbled on its second play from scrimmage, and Cathers pounced on it at the Cavaliers 31. The Sals took eight plays to punch it in, with Garrett Cannon crossing the line on a 2-yard keeper to make it 7-0 with 4:25 left in the opening quarter. 
Sallies’ next big play was an interception, as a Middletown pass deflected off a receiver and into the hands of Evan Mullin at the Cavaliers 8. The senior linebacker returned it to the 2, and Reeder took a toss to the left to score on the next play. The PAT was blocked, leaving the Sals with a 13-0 lead with 10:19 to go in the second quarter. 
Middletown’s next drive was stopped when Easton jumped on a loose ball at the Cavaliers 36. After a Sallies punt, Vincent DelPercio flipped a screen pass to Kedrick Whitehead that appeared to go for a 68-yard Middletown TD. But the Cavaliers were whistled for an illegal man downfield. 
Salesianum moved into position to score again, but the Cavaliers picked off a pass at their own 5 with 19 seconds left in the half. 
Salesianum quarterback Garrett Cannon looks for a receiver in the second quarter of the Sals' 20-6 win at Baynard Stadium Friday. (Photo: WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNA) 
Then Middletown really seized the momentum to start the second half. Whitehead took a simple handoff up the middle on the Cavaliers’ first play and went 74 yards untouched. The PAT was blocked, but Middletown pulled within 13-6. 
“The one play that they scored big on, I was kind of disappointed,” DiNardo said. “But that’s football, and they’re a talented team. That’s a lesson for us, you can’t let down on any play.” 
The charged-up Cavaliers forced a punt, but fumbled on their next play. Easton was in the right place at the right time, and the senior lineman recovered it at the Middletown 25. Griffin Salvo took a reverse all the way on the next play, and just like that the Sals’ lead was up to 20-6. 
Middletown (3-2) didn’t give up, as DelPercio consistently completed short passes to move the ball down the field. But the Cavaliers fumbled again on first-and-10 from the Sallies 20, and Cathers fell on it to extinguish another drive with 7:52 to play. 
The Cavaliers forced a punt, and moved inside the 10 on three DelPercio completions. But the Sals’ defense came up big again, as linebacker Will Stradley broke through to stop Whitehead for a 1-yard loss on fourth-and-1 at the 3 with 3:12 remaining. 
DelPercio completed 15 of 25 passes for 117 yards. But outside of Whitehead’s one big run, Middletown’s other 23 carries went for minus-2 yards.
